entry.title: Re: Table to fetch the Title & the Address of the URL
entry.content:
For GOS “Create external document (URL)”, the Title is stored in SOOD.
The URL/address itself is stored in table SOC3 (field depending on SAP release), not in SOFFCONT1.
URLs and notes are handled as SAPoffice documents; only PC attachments may go to SOFFCONT1/KPro.
Refer to SAP Note 530792 for the exact storage behavior.

entry.title: Re: SOC3 and SOFFCOUNT1 Archiving
entry.content:
SOC3 data can be archived using standard SAP tools such as report RSSOAPUT (BCS archiving).
However, SOFFCONT1 does not support archiving via SAP Archive Development Kit. Entries can only be deleted/reorganized (for example using RSBCS_REORG or by relocating content to a content server via RSIRPIRL).
Always test thoroughly before executing in production.

entry.title: Re: Find were the actual attachment is stored in table.
entry.content:
SOC3 data can be archived using report RSSOAPUT (after proper testing).
SOFFCONT1 cannot be archived via SAP archiving objects; it can only be deleted/reorganized using RSBCS_REORG or relocated to a content server using RSIRPIRL.
SAP does not provide a standard archive object for SOFFCONT1.

entry.title: Re: Moivng contents of SOC3 table to Content server
entry.content:
SOC3 data cannot be migrated to a Content Server in the same way as SOFFCONT1.

SOFFCONT1 stores large binary content managed via KPro and can be relocated to a Content Server using RSIRPIRL.

SOC3 mainly contains small contents such as notes, URLs, and metadata, and is not designed for KPro-based content server relocation. SAP does not provide any standard tool or procedure to move SOC3 content to a Content Server.

The supported approach for SOC3 is SAP Office archiving/deletion, for example using report RSSOAPUT, after proper testing.

If SOC3 is growing significantly, review usage patterns and housekeeping rather than content server migration.

entry.title: Re: Regarding the SAP big tables in ECC 6.0
entry.content:
These are standard SAP tables that typically grow over time.
• TST03 – Spool data; clean up using RSPO0041 / RSPO1041 and reorganize if oversized.
• COEP – CO line items; reduce size via CO archiving objects in SARA.
• SOFFCONT1 – SAP Office document content; reduce via reorganization/relocation (e.g. RSIRPIRL) and deletion policies.
• GLPCA – PCA line items; archive using EC-PCA archiving objects.
• EDI40 – IDoc data; delete/archive old IDocs (WE11 / SAP Note 40088).
Refer to the SAP Database Management Guide and relevant SAP Notes for prevention and cleanup.

entry.title: Re: After import table content is missing
entry.content: This is the correct approach for recovering SOFFCONT1 after an incomplete Unicode migration. Using R3load -merge_bck preserves newly created data and avoids overwriting active records. Important to validate dependencies and test carefully before production use.

entry.title: Re: Most allocated extents in any segment oracle 11g
entry.content:
For Oracle 11g with locally managed tablespaces, a high number of extents (even for LOB segments like SOFFCONT1) is not an issue because MAX_EXTENTS is UNLIMITED and extent sizes are managed automatically.
This CCMS alert is informational only. No action is required unless you see real space or performance problems.
Refer SAP Note 483856 for details.

entry.title: Re: How the project attachment file link to project?
entry.content:
In CJ20N, project attachments are linked via Generic Object Services (GOS) / BDS.
The relationship between the project (object type BUS2054 / PROJ) and attachments is stored in SRGBTBREL.
For SAPoffice attachments, document data is held in SOOD / SOFM / SOC3 / SOFFCONT1.

To retrieve attachments programmatically, use BDS_ALL_CONNECTIONS_GET (for BDS/ArchiveLink) or GOS APIs.
SAP Note 530792 explains the storage and linkage in detail.

entry.title: Re: Unknown objects in ABAP Dictionary
entry.content:
The unknown object SOFFCONT1#$ is a leftover from an interrupted BRSPACE table reorganization. It can be safely removed using:
brspace -f tbreorg -t SOFFCONT1#$ -a cleanup.

The SAP_AUXSTATS DB view belongs to DBA Cockpit/Oracle statistics and may appear as “unknown” in older Basis releases. No manual action is recommended—open an SAP incident if the warning persists.

entry.title: Re: Content Server Table for REBDPR Tcode
entry.content: Attachments in REBDPR are handled via SAPoffice. SOFFLOIO / SOFFPHIO store the logical & physical document references, while the actual content is stored in SOFFCONT1 (or an external content server if configured). See SAP Note 904711 for full details. SQL/ABAP trace during upload can confirm the flow.

entry.title: Re: Reduce size LOBSEGMENT
entry.content: Deleting entries from SOFFCONT1 does not automatically shrink the associated LOB segment. For LOBs, space is not released unless the LOB is moved or rebuilt. You need to reorganize the LOB segment explicitly (e.g. BRSPACE LOB reorg or MOVE LOB), or relocate content to a content server (RSIRPIRL). Otherwise, the LOB size remaining large is expected behavior.

entry.title: Re: what is the procedure to transfer attached documents...
entry.content:
There is no supported way to transfer attachments by transporting SOFFCONT1. Attachments are part of SAPoffice/KPro and must be moved using standard relocation tools.

If attachments are stored in the database, use RSIRPIRL to relocate them to a Content Server. If they are already on a Content Server, configure the new repository (OAC0/OACT/SKPR08) and perform a content server migration using SAP‑supported tools (repository copy or vendor tools like OpenText).

Transporting SOFFCONT1 is not recommended and can lead to inconsistencies.

entry.title: Re: Content Repository Migration in mind ? Part IV Error in Migration
entry.content: Thanks for the detailed explanation. For Content Repository migration errors, checking SLG1 logs (objects SDOK and SCMS) is crucial to identify whether the issue is at the source or target repository. Verifying the target repository with RSCMST / RSCMSTH0 before reruns also helps avoid partial or inconsistent migrations. This blog is very helpful for troubleshooting RSIRPIRL-related issues.

entry.title: Re: systemVars.dimensions.viewport.height malfunction
entry.content: Apparently, this issue appears on some devices e.g. on Android 16, while older devices, e.g. Android 11 work properly!

entry.title: Re: Archiving Emails in CRM
entry.content: Email archiving in CRM is not done via WORKITEM archiving alone. Attachments are stored in SOFFCONT1 and should be relocated using RSIRPIRL to a content server. Email body/text stored in SOC3 / SAPoffice can be archived via SOY8. WORKITEM archiving is only relevant if emails are processed via SAP Connect workflow. SAP Note 904711 gives a good overview.

entry.title: Re: Dynamic table name in Select * From (Table_name)
entry.content:
you can select the data but that won't help you at all,
because there is no dynamic data target.

entry.title: Re: Row Compression in db2 9.7
entry.content: TST03 growth is mainly driven by LOB data, so DB2 row compression has limited effect. Best approach is housekeeping as per SAP Note 48400 or increasing INLINE LENGTH for the LOB. For SOFFCONT1, moving content to an external repository is recommended.

entry.title: TMS External Planning via CPI
entry.content:
There are many situations where a TMS application must connect with external or 3rd‑party systems such as JDE, MercuryGate, or legacy home‑grown applications. These integrations are typically implemented to exchange transportation data, automate business transactions, and maintain end-to-end visibility across the supply chain.

 

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/e3dc5400c1cc41d1bc0ae0e7fd9aa5a2/5505d7ffe42c496788d504e54ce80e59.html?locale=en-US

In a typical SAP TM landscape, standard SAP integration enables the system to send Freight Units (FUs) to an external or 3rd‑party Transportation Management application (such as JDE, MercuryGate, or a legacy system) without requiring any custom development.

The standard process works as follows:

  1. SAP TM creates Freight Units (FUs) based on sales orders, purchase orders, or deliveries.
  2. These FUs are sent to the 3rd‑party TMS using SAP’s out‑of‑the‑box integration capabilities ( CPI,).
  3. The external TMS performs:
    • Load planning
    • Carrier selection
    • Routing
    • Tendering
  4. The 3rd‑party system then sends routing and carrier assignment confirmation back to SAP TM using the standard interface.
  5. SAP TM automatically:
    • Creates a Freight Order (FO) based on the received planning data
    • Links the FO to the original Freight Unit
    • Consumes the FU (i.e., the FU becomes assigned to the FO)

All of this is supported by SAP’s standard integration content, which means no custom development is required for core message flows or planning confirmation processing.

Configuration Steps : 

1. Enable the PPF action : TOR_TPNOR_FU at FU level using 

2. Activate the services in SICF 

3. Check the SRT_ADMIN report for Webservice and Task Watcher readiness (SAP support team help need to run the SRT_ADMIN in 000 client via serivce ticket)

4. Create SOAP endpoint in CPI

5. Expose/obtain the WSDL for that endpoint (from CPI).

6. Create Logical Port in SOAMANAGER for your DEV  unit test client

 How to Test : 

Here’s a clean, step‑by‑step way to Generate a Freight Unit (FU) in SAP TM and verify that the PPF action triggers successfully and XML is generated for outbound integration — exactly what you'd check during FU → 3rd‑party integration testing.

For any errors , please check the tcode SRT_UTIL 

Summary : 

1. S/4 to External Planning system : TransportationOrderGenericRequest_Out

2. External Planning System to S/4 : TransportationOrderGenericRequest_In

If you want to receive charges from the external planning system, you must use the additional web service TransportationOrderChargeElementRequest_In, as charge transfers are not covered by the standard inbound service TransportationOrderGenericRequest_In.

 
Would like to share my findings with SAP community!

Thank you
Hari Sivvala

entry.title: Re: where is the attached file stored in ECC6.0?
entry.content:
In ECC 6.0, attachments (texts, screenshots, files) are typically stored in table SOFFCONT1 (content), with metadata in SOOD / SOFM.
There is no fixed SAP limit, but large attachments increase database size, so SAP recommends moving them to a Content Server

entry.title: Re: Statement Level Trigger (SQL Anywhere 17)
entry.content:
To get the clean output, I chained a GREP command to the output of the dbmanageetd  basedon  SYS_Audit_String search pattern. This could also be handled with a regular expression if you do not have a grep tool on the system.

My last suggested delete trigger has a counter in the fetch loop that is used to detect and report a no-op delete statement.  If the counter is 0 after processing the NEW temp table, it means that the delete statement was a no-op.  In that case,, an audit string  "No row impacted by DELETE"  is logged. Note that this will only work with statement level triggers. and  It is really a rough idea of how this could be implemented.

entry.title: Re: what are the SAP inbox tables.
entry.content:
SAP Inbox (SBWP) data is mainly retrieved from workflow and SAPoffice tables.
Key tables include:

  • SWWUSERWI – workflow work items for a specific user (main inbox driver)

  • SWWWIHEAD / SWWWIAGENT – work item header and agent assignment

  • SOC3 – SAPoffice document content (mail/body)

  • SOOD / SOOS – SAPoffice document headers and status

  • SOFFCONT1 – attachments

A large inbox (e.g. 37k entries) usually causes timeout due to SWWUSERWI volume.
Using workflow archiving and inbox cleanup is recommended.

entry.title: Re: Reorganize/Archive SAPOffice documents
entry.content:
Your understanding is largely correct.

  • RSBCS_REORG deletes SAPoffice documents (cleanup, not real archiving).

  • Mass archiving of historical SAPoffice documents (e.g. year-based) is not supported by SAP standard.

  • Documents can be stored in a content repository via storage category configuration, but this applies mainly to newly created documents.

  • For existing documents, realistic options are deletion via RSBCS_REORG / SOY5 / SOY8 or using third‑party tools to move content from SOFFCONT1 to an external repository.

entry.title: Re: TDMS functionality question - Time slice scenario
entry.content:
In TDMS time-based slice scenarios, SAP Office tables (including SOFFCONT1) are not transferred. Attachments stored in SOFFCONT1 are excluded, while DMS tables like DMS_CONT1_CD1 are transferred in full.

By default, TDMS excludes SAP Office, Workflow, Change Docs, Users/Roles, Variants, and similar technical data.
Time-based scenarios transfer full master data + reduced transactional data.
Runtime depends heavily on hardware, parallel jobs, and table sizes—there’s no reliable generic estimate.

entry.title: Re: Table still fragmented after REORG !!
entry.content: Conclusion: PCL2 is not actually fragmented. The high “wasted space” reported by the script from SAP Note 821687 is misleading because the table contains a LOB (BLOB) column. When analyzed with DBMS_SPACE (Note 1295200 / 1438410), fragmentation is minimal and UNUSED_MB is low. REORG was therefore not required

entry.title: Re: Prevent tables from loading into memory
entry.content: You cannot prevent tables from loading into HANA memory. Unload priority only affects when they are unloaded. Best practice is to archive/reorganize workflow and PI tables, and move SOFFCONT1 attachments to an external content repository (per SAP Note 1634908). Dynamic tiering can also be considered for warm data.

entry.title: Re: Database error <>
entry.content:
We faced the same Database error <GET DATA FROM KPRO> issue after upgrade.
Root cause was missing SOFFCONT1 content for old PHIOs due to incomplete data during system copy/upgrade.
Restoring affected documents from backup resolved the issue.
New documents were unaffected.

entry.title: Re: Where SAP store the uploaded files?
entry.content:
Uploaded files are not stored automatically by SAP.
In Web Dynpro, the FileUpload UI element only holds the file temporarily in memory (XSTRING).
The application decides where to store it:

  • SAP Office / KPro → SOFFCONT1 (or Content Server if configured)

  • DMS / GOS / ArchiveLink → external content repository

  • Custom logic → database table or application server (AL11)

Physical storage is explained in SAP Note 904711.

entry.title: Re: Is Selective Data Transition the Best Fit for Your SA...
entry.content:
There is no single “best” migration approach for all customers.
The right choice between Brownfield, Greenfield, or Selective Data Transition (SDT) depends on business goals, system complexity, data volume, and transformation scope.

  • Brownfield fits customers who want a faster technical conversion with minimal process change.

  • Greenfield is ideal when major process redesign and clean-core adoption are priorities.

  • Selective Data Transition works well when customers need to retain specific historical data and critical processes while still modernizing selectively.

A detailed assessment of data, custom code, timelines, and business readiness is essential before deciding the migration path.

entry.title: Getting Unconventional with Groovy - Part 2 - connecting to SAP CI's underlying postgree DB
entry.content:
Introduction:

Before I start this let me share that this article is just for the curious bunch of people. I am not recommending you to connect to postgree db of SAP CI for any productive scenarios.

SAP CI exposes the following credentials / private keys in System Env variable VCAP_SERVICES

Security Credentials Exposed in VCAP_SERVICES

Exposed Credentials and Keys

Database Credentials (PostgreSQL)

  • Risk Level: CRITICAL
  • Plain text username and password
  • Full database connection strings with hostname, port, dbname
  • SSL certificates (root CA certificates)
  • Direct access to production database with full CRUD permissions

Certificate-Based Authentication (Multiple Services)

  • Risk Level: CRITICAL
  • X.509 client certificates (full certificate chains)
  • Private RSA keys (PKCS#8 and PEM formats) for:
    • Connectivity service
    • Enterprise messaging
    • Destination service
    • XSUAA (authentication)
    • Kafka
  • These private keys provide identity proof and decrypt capabilities

OAuth2 / XSUAA Tokens

  • Risk Level: CRITICAL
  • Client IDs and client secrets
  • Token endpoints and verification keys
  • Service instance IDs
  • Tenant/zone identifiers

Kafka Credentials

  • Risk Level: HIGH
  • Username and password for Kafka authentication
  • Client certificates and private keys
  • Broker endpoints (hostnames and ports)
  • Topic-level permissions mapping

Credential Store Encryption Keys

  • Risk Level: CRITICAL
  • Client private keys for encryption
  • Server public keys
  • OAuth credentials for accessing the credential store itself
  • Access policy definitions showing what namespaces can be accessed

Azure Blob Storage

  • Risk Level: HIGH
  • Storage account names
  • SAS (Shared Access Signature) tokens with full container access
  • Container URIs and region information

Dynatrace APM

  • Risk Level: MEDIUM
  • API tokens with environment access
  • Environment IDs
  • API URLs

Connectivity Service

  • Risk Level: CRITICAL
  • On-premise proxy hostnames and ports
  • Certificates and private keys
  • Access to Cloud Connector for hybrid connectivity

As I have maintained this is a security risk and SAP should plug this. Username and Passwords SHOULD NOT be available/visible at all in VCAP_SERVICES file.

anyways..here is a groovy script that finds out all the tables on the postgree sql db, lists them and also lists top 10 rows from each table. 

This is only a read operation and does not modify the db in any way.

 

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message;
import groovy.sql.Sql;
import groovy.json.JsonSlurper;

def Message processData(Message message) {
    def body = message.getBody(java.lang.String);
    DatabaseManager db = null
    
    try {
        def vcapJson = java.lang.System.getenv("VCAP_SERVICES")
        def vcap = new JsonSlurper().parseText(vcapJson)
        def psql = vcap."postgresql-db"[0].credentials
        
        def psql_username = psql.username
        def psql_password = psql.password
        def psql_hostname = psql.hostname
        def psql_port = psql.port
        def psql_dbname = psql.dbname
        
        db = new DatabaseManager(
            psql_hostname + ":" + psql_port, 
            psql_dbname, 
            psql_username, 
            psql_password
        )
        
        Sql sql = db.getSql();
        def tables = []
        
        // If body is empty, get all tables first
        if (body == null || body.trim().isEmpty()) {
            def tableQuery = """
                SELECT table_name 
                FROM information_schema.tables 
                WHERE table_schema = 'public' 
                AND table_type = 'BASE TABLE'
                ORDER BY table_name
            """
            def tableResults = sql.rows(tableQuery)
            tables = tableResults.collect { it.table_name }
        } else {
            // Parse JSON array from body
            def jsonSlurper = new JsonSlurper()
            def parsed = jsonSlurper.parseText(body)
            
            if (parsed instanceof List) {
                parsed.each { item ->
                    if (item instanceof String) {
                        tables.add(item)
                    } else if (item instanceof Map && item.table_name) {
                        tables.add(item.table_name)
                    }
                }
            }
        }
        
        def output = new StringBuilder()
        output.append("{\n")
        output.append("  \"_meta\": {\"tables_scanned\": ${tables.size()}, \"timestamp\": \"${new Date().format('yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss')}\"},\n")
        
        tables.eachWithIndex { tableName, tableIdx ->
            output.append("  \"${tableName}\": {\n")
            
            try {
                // Get row count
                def countResult = sql.firstRow("SELECT COUNT(*) as cnt FROM \"${tableName}\"".toString())
                def rowCount = countResult?.cnt ?: 0
                output.append("    \"total_rows\": ${rowCount},\n")
                
                // Get columns with types
                def colQuery = """
                    SELECT column_name, data_type 
                    FROM information_schema.columns 
                    WHERE table_name = '${tableName}' 
                    ORDER BY ordinal_position
                """.toString()
                def columns = sql.rows(colQuery)
                output.append("    \"columns\": [")
                output.append(columns.collect { "\"${it.column_name}(${it.data_type})\"" }.join(", "))
                output.append("],\n")
                
                // Get top 10 rows
                def rows = sql.rows("SELECT * FROM \"${tableName}\" LIMIT 10".toString())
                output.append("    \"data\": [\n")
                
                rows.eachWithIndex { row, rowIdx ->
                    output.append("      {")
                    def cols = []
                    row.each { key, value ->
                        def valStr = sanitizeValue(value)
                        cols.add("\"${key}\": \"${valStr}\"")
                    }
                    output.append(cols.join(", "))
                    output.append("}")
                    if (rowIdx < rows.size() - 1) output.append(",")
                    output.append("\n")
                }
                
                output.append("    ]\n")
                
            } catch (Exception e) {
                output.append("    \"error\": \"${e.message.replaceAll('"', "'").take(200)}\"\n")
            }
            
            output.append("  }")
            if (tableIdx < tables.size() - 1) output.append(",")
            output.append("\n")
        }
        
        output.append("}")
        message.setBody(output.toString())
        
    } catch (Exception e) {
        message.setBody("ERROR: ${e.message}\n\nStack: ${e.stackTrace.take(10).join('\n')}")
    } finally {
        if (db != null) {
            db.close()
        }
    }
    
    return message;
}

def String sanitizeValue(Object value) {
    if (value == null) return "null"
    
    def str = value.toString()
    
    // Handle binary/byte arrays
    if (value instanceof byte[]) {
        str = "[BINARY: ${value.length} bytes]"
    }
    
    // Truncate, escape quotes and newlines
    str = str.take(500)
        .replaceAll('\\\\', '\\\\\\\\')
        .replaceAll('"', '\\\\"')
        .replaceAll('\n', '\\\\n')
        .replaceAll('\r', '\\\\r')
        .replaceAll('\t', '\\\\t')
    
    return str
}

class DatabaseManager {
    private Sql sql
    private boolean isConnected = false
    
    DatabaseManager(String hostPort, String database, String username, String password) {
        String jdbcUrl = "jdbc:postgresql://${hostPort}/${database}?sslmode=require"
        try {
            this.sql = Sql.newInstance(jdbcUrl, username, password, "org.postgresql.Driver")
            this.isConnected = true
        } catch (Exception e) {
            throw new RuntimeException("Failed to connect to database: ${e.message}", e)
        }
    }
    
    Sql getSql() {
        if (!isConnected) {
            throw new IllegalStateException("Database connection is closed")
        }
        return sql
    }
    
    void close() {
        if (sql != null && isConnected) {
            sql.close()
            isConnected = false
        }
    }
}

 

But lets not stop here. SAP must have given these creds in plaintext for a reason and maybe we should go ahead and create a table of our own and insert some values as well.

 

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message;
import groovy.sql.Sql;
import groovy.json.JsonSlurper;

def Message processData(Message message) {
    def body = message.getBody(java.lang.String);
    DatabaseManager db = null
    
    try {
        def vcapJson = java.lang.System.getenv("VCAP_SERVICES")
        def vcap = new JsonSlurper().parseText(vcapJson)
        def psql = vcap."postgresql-db"[0].credentials
        
        def psql_username = psql.username
        def psql_password = psql.password
        def psql_hostname = psql.hostname
        def psql_port = psql.port
        def psql_dbname = psql.dbname
        
        db = new DatabaseManager(
            "${psql_hostname}:${psql_port}", 
            psql_dbname, 
            psql_username, 
            psql_password
        )
        
        Sql sql = db.getSql();
        def output = new StringBuilder()
        
        // Create table
        output.append("=== Creating Table ===\n")
        sql.execute('''
            CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS test_table (
                id SERIAL PRIMARY KEY,
                name VARCHAR(100),
                created_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP
            )
        '''.toString())
        output.append("Table 'test_table' created successfully\n\n")
        
        // Insert row
        output.append("=== Inserting Row ===\n")
        def timestamp = new Date().format('yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss')
        def insertSQL = 'INSERT INTO test_table (name) VALUES (?) RETURNING id, name, created_at'
        def insertedRow = sql.firstRow(insertSQL, ["Test Entry ${timestamp}".toString()])
        output.append("Inserted row: ID=${insertedRow.id}, Name=${insertedRow.name}, Created=${insertedRow.created_at}\n\n")
        
        // Select and display results
        output.append("=== Selecting All Rows ===\n")
        def selectSQL = 'SELECT * FROM test_table ORDER BY id DESC LIMIT 10'
        def rows = sql.rows(selectSQL)
        
        output.append("Found ${rows.size()} row(s):\n")
        rows.each { row ->
            output.append("  ID: ${row.id} | Name: ${row.name} | Created: ${row.created_at}\n")
        }
        
        message.setBody(output.toString())
        
    } catch (Exception e) {
        message.setBody("ERROR: ${e.message}\n\nStack: ${e.stackTrace.take(10).join('\n')}")
    } finally {
        if (db != null) {
            db.close()
        }
    }
    
    return message;
}

class DatabaseManager {
    private Sql sql
    private boolean isConnected = false
    
    DatabaseManager(String hostPort, String database, String username, String password) {
        String jdbcUrl = "jdbc:postgresql://${hostPort}/${database}?sslmode=require"
        try {
            this.sql = Sql.newInstance(jdbcUrl, username, password, "org.postgresql.Driver")
            this.isConnected = true
        } catch (Exception e) {
            throw new RuntimeException("Failed to connect to database: ${e.message}", e)
        }
    }
    
    Sql getSql() {
        if (!isConnected) {
            throw new IllegalStateException("Database connection is closed")
        }
        return sql
    }
    
    void close() {
        if (sql != null && isConnected) {
            sql.close()
            isConnected = false
        }
    }
}

Result

=== Creating Table ===
Table 'test_table' created successfully

=== Inserting Row ===
Inserted row: ID=3, Name=Test Entry 2025-12-24 04:52:04, Created=2025-12-24 04:52:04.248478

=== Selecting All Rows ===
Found 3 row(s):
  ID: 3 | Name: Test Entry 2025-12-24 04:52:04 | Created: 2025-12-24 04:52:04.248478
  ID: 2 | Name: Test Entry 2025-12-24 04:52:02 | Created: 2025-12-24 04:52:02.147281
  ID: 1 | Name: Test Entry 2025-12-24 04:51:55 | Created: 2025-12-24 04:51:55.597395

 

This script will perhaps help SAP CI developers understand how certain things work in SAP CI at the database level.

Again I am not encouraging anyone to modify the postgree db of SAP CI and this is only here for the curious bunch.

entry.title: Re: Data migration is quite slow
entry.content: This is not expected behavior for such a small and simple material dataset. Even with multiple plant extensions, 13 hours for ~5,000 materials indicates a performance or configuration issue. Common causes include background job bottlenecks, system resource constraints in the Q system, or validations/enhancements triggered during migration. Splitting files helps only as a workaround. I recommend raising an SAP incident under CA-GTF-MIG with migration logs so SAP can analyze the runtime and identify the exact performance bottleneck.

entry.title: Re: Quick Apply
entry.content:
Hi @Melissa_S ,

SAP SuccessFactors Recruiting Quick Apply allows candidates to submit applications with minimal fields, reducing drop-offs and improving conversion—especially for high-volume roles.

What to Consider Before Enabling Quick Apply

  • Name

  • Email

  • Resume (optional but recommended)

Lesson learned

  • Adding phone, location, or custom fields defeats the purpose and hurts conversion.

  • Capture extra data later via Candidate Profile Update or Onboarding.

Candidate Profile vs Application Fields

Important decision

  • Decide which data belongs to:

    • Candidate Profile (long-term data)

    • Application (job-specific)

Lesson learned

  • If fields are mandatory in the candidate profile, Quick Apply will still prompt them → causes confusion.

✔️ Ensure profile fields are not mandatory for Quick Apply roles.

Resume Parsing Can Be a Bottleneck

Reality

  • Resume parsing quality depends on format.

Lesson learned

  • Poor parsing → empty fields → recruiter complaints.

  • Avoid auto-reject rules based on parsed fields during early stages.

Use resume mainly for recruiter review, not filtering.

Compliance & Legal Requirements

Critical

  • GDPR, EEOC, diversity, consent checkboxes

Lesson learned

  • Legal teams often insist on mandatory compliance fields.

  • This can clash with Quick Apply simplicity.

✔️ Solution:

  • Keep only mandatory legal consents

  • Push diversity info to post-apply surveys if possible.

Role-Based Configuration

Not all jobs should use Quick Apply

  • High-volume, entry-level, frontline roles

  • Executive, niche, compliance-heavy roles

Lesson learned

  • Create separate job requisition templates:

    • Quick Apply template

    • Standard Apply template

Mobile Experience Is the Real Test

Most Quick Apply candidates apply via mobile.

Lesson learned

  • Fields that look fine on desktop can break mobile UX.

  • Long consent text = high abandonment.

✔️ Always test:

  • Mobile apply

  • Resume upload from phone

  • Autofill behavior

Integration Impact (RMK / Career Site)

If using:

  • Recruiting Marketing (RMK)

  • External career site

Lesson learned

  • Quick Apply must be enabled and styled consistently across:

    • CSB / RMK

    • Brand pages

  • Misalignment causes candidates to see different flows.

Reporting & Funnel Tracking

Expect changes in metrics:

  • More applications

  • Lower initial data quality

  • Higher recruiter screening effort

Lesson learned

  • Update recruiting KPIs:

    • Track conversion, not just completion

    • Compare Quick Apply vs Standard Apply performance

Recommended Implementation Checklist

✔️ Minimal mandatory fields
✔️ Non-mandatory candidate profile fields
✔️ Compliance reviewed & approved
✔️ Separate requisition templates
✔️ Mobile testing completed
✔️ Recruiters trained on lower-data applications
✔️ Reporting expectations reset

Thanks,

kr,

karthick,

entry.title: Re: Applying the Right Sizing Method and Using the Right Sizing Tool
entry.content:
Hi Arjun,
For SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition (RISE), resizing is handled via SAP rather than directly by customers.

Typically, you should:
• Monitor current usage (HANA memory, CPU, disk, workload trends)
• Validate growth using /SDF/HDB_SIZING and EarlyWatch / SAP Readiness Check
• Raise a request through SAP (or your RISE contract partner) for scale‑up or scale‑down

SAP then evaluates feasibility and performs resizing based on contractual limits and technical validation.

This approach ensures stability while still benefiting from cloud elasticity under RISE.

Hope this helps.

entry.title: Re: Total amount of candidates in story reports
entry.content:
Hi @Alina ,

Candidate counts are always derived from Job Applications, not directly from Job Requisitions.

1.Create a New Story Report

  • Go to Reporting → Create → Story Report

  • Choose Job Application as the Data Source

2. Select Required Fields

Add the following fields to your report:

From Job Application

  • Job Application ID (or Candidate ID)

From Job Requisition (via association)

  • Job Requisition ID

  • Job Requisition Title / Requisition Number

3. Use an Aggregation (This is the Key Part)

  • Change visualization to Table

  • For Job Application ID:

    • Set Aggregation = Count

  • For Job Requisition ID:

    • Set Aggregation = Group By

This automatically gives you: Total candidates per requisition

4. (Optional) Filter What You Want to Count

You can refine the count using filters like:

  • Application Status = Active

  • Candidate Status ≠ Declined

  • Internal vs External Candidates

  • Date Applied (e.g., last 30 days)

 Output

Requisition ID Requisition Title Candidate Count
JR-1001SAP Consultant42
JR-1002HR Analyst18

Hope this helps!!

Thanks,

kr,

karthick.

entry.title: Leveraging SAP AI Core to Build Custom AI Agents with CrewAI
entry.content:
Introduction

AI agents are becoming the go-to pattern for building modular, autonomous assistants that can think, act, and collaborate. CrewAI gives you a developer-friendly way to orchestrate these agents, while SAP AI Core provides enterprise-grade access to LLMs with proper governance, scalability, and security.

This quickstart shows you how to connect CrewAI to SAP AI Core, create a custom LLM interface, and build your first working agent — all in under 10 minutes.

By the end, you’ll have a simple CrewAI agent powered by an LLM hosted in SAP AI Core.

 

How SAP Facilitates Building Custom Agents

CrewAI handles the agent orchestration layer, while SAP AI Core hosts and manages your LLMs.  

Connecting them allows you to use SAP’s AI infrastructure directly inside your CrewAI workflows — no external API juggling.

Here’s the high-level flow:

User Prompt → CrewAI Agent → Custom LLM Class → SAP AI Core Endpoint → Model Response

Flow summary:

  1. User sends a prompt → CrewAI Agent receives it.
  2. Agent forwards it to a custom LLM wrapper (`SAPAILLM`).
  3. The wrapper authenticates using the token and sends the request to SAP AI Core.
  4. SAP AI Core executes the model and returns a response to the agent.
  5. CrewAI handles the output and delivers the final answer.

This setup ensures enterprise-level reliability with full control over which models your agents use.

 

Prerequisites

Before jumping in, make sure you have:

  • Access to SAP AI Core with deployed LLM models (via AI Launchpad)
  • Python 3.10+
  • VS Code or your favorite IDE
  • Installed libraries:
pip install ipykernel
pip install crewai
pip install crewai_tools
pip install generative-ai-hub-sdk[all]
pip install langchain_community
  • Your SAP AI Core Service Key downloaded as a .json file
  • Your A-game to create some amazing agents

*If you want to learn how to deploy your LLM model on launchpad, you can go through this course.

 

Step-by-Step Guide

Let us now dive into building our own custom agent which utilizes SAP's AI Core.

Step 1: Get Your SAP AI Core Credentials

In your SAP BTP Cockpit → AI Core Instance → Service Keys, create a new key and save it locally as credentials.json.

Example structure:

{
    "clientid": "your-client-id",
    "clientsecret": "your-client-secret",
    "url": "https://<your-region>.authentication.sap.hana.ondemand.com",
    "serviceurls": {
        "AI_API_URL": "https://***.aws.ml.hana.ondemand.com"
    }
}

This file contains everything needed to authenticate and access your deployed LLM.

Step 2: Get Your BTP LLM Access Token

We’ll use this token to authenticate each request to SAP AI Core.

import json, requests

# open credentials file
with open("<path-to-file>/credentials.json", "r") as key_file:
    svcKey = json.load(key_file)
authUrl = svcKey["url"]
clientid = svcKey["clientid"]
clientsecret = svcKey["clientsecret"]
apiUrl = svcKey["serviceurls"]["AI_API_URL"]

# request token
params = {"grant_type": "client_credentials" }
resp = requests.post(f"{authUrl}/oauth/token",
                    auth=(clientid, clientsecret),
                    params=params)

BtpLlmAccessToken = resp.json()["access_token"]
print("Token retrieved successfully!")

Tokens usually expire after 1 hour. Make sure to refresh them before making multiple requests.

Step 3: Create a Custom LLM Class Template for CrewAI

CrewAI lets you define your own LLM wrappers, which means we can make one that talks directly to SAP AI Core.

In this class, we can define the procedure to use the deployed models from SAP AI Core.

You can now import this class into any CrewAI workflow to use SAP’s hosted LLMs.

from crewai import BaseLLM
from typing import Any, Dict, List, Optional, Union

class CustomLLM(BaseLLM):
    def __init__(self, model: str, api_key: str, endpoint: str, temperature: Optional[float] = None):
        super().__init__(model=model, temperature=temperature)

        self.api_key = api_key
        self.endpoint = endpoint

    def call(
        self,
        messages: Union[str, List[Dict[str, str]]],
        tools: Optional[List[dict]] = None,
        **kwargs
    ) -> Union[str, Any]:
        """Call the LLM with the given messages."""
        # Convert string to message format if needed
        if isinstance(messages, str):
            messages = [{"role": "user", "content": messages}]

        payload = {
            "messages": messages,
            "temperature": self.temperature,
            "max_tokens": 1000 # This can be modified as per your use case. You can parameterize this as well.
        }

        headers = {
            'AI-Resource-Group': "<your-resource-group-name>",
            'Content-Type': 'application/json',
            'Authorization': f'Bearer {BtpLlmAccessToken}',
        }

        # Make API call
        response = requests.post(
            self.endpoint,
            headers= headers,
            json=payload,
            timeout=30
        )
        response.raise_for_status()

        result = response.json()
        return result["choices"][0]["message"]["content"]

Step 4: Initialize your Custom LLM Class

Alright, time to bring that class to life.  

The cool thing here is that you can hook it up to any model you’ve deployed in SAP AI Core, whether it’s GPT-4o, Claude, or your own fine-tuned beast.

In this example, we’ll wire it up to a **GPT-4o** deployment and let CrewAI start chatting through it. You can get the deployment endpoint from your SAP AI Launchpad. You can find the payload formats for different models here.

deployment_url = "<deployment URL>" + "/chat/completions?api-version=2024-02-01"

# instantiating Custom LLM object
custom_llm = CustomLLM(
    model="gpt-4o",
    api_key=BtpLlmAccessToken,
    endpoint=deployment_url,
    temperature=0.7
)

Step 5: Build a Simple CrewAI Agent

Now that your LLM class is ready, let’s create a basic Research CrewAI agent that uses it.

from crewai import Agent, Task, Crew

# Load credentials
agent = Agent(
    role="Research Assistant",
    goal="Find and analyze information",
    backstory="You serve as a research assistant, helping to gather and analyze information about SAP tools and related topics.",
    llm=custom_llm
)

# Create and execute tasks
task = Task(
    description="Research the latest developments in SAP AI Core",
    expected_output="A comprehensive summary",
    agent=agent
)

crew = Crew(agents=[agent], tasks=[task])
result = crew.kickoff()

If all goes well, you’ll see a clean response from your SAP-hosted LLM, directly through your CrewAI agent. Here is a sample output:

CrewOutput(raw="The latest developments in SAP AI Core focus on enhancing the capabilities for deploying and managing AI models in a scalable and efficient manner. SAP AI Core is part of SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) and is designed to integrate with other SAP applications to streamline AI operat....ding tools that enhance productivity, and driving innovation through AI-powered solutions.", pydantic=None, json_dict=None, agent='Research Assistant', output_format=<OutputFormat.RAW: 'raw'>)], token_usage=UsageMetrics(total_tokens=0, prompt_tokens=0, cached_prompt_tokens=0, completion_tokens=0, successful_requests=0))

 

Conclusion

And that’s it — you just built your first CrewAI agent powered by SAP AI Core.

From here, you can:

  • Add tools for the agent to interact with SAP APIs (e.g., fetching invoice data).
  • Add memory and multi-agent orchestration.
  • Deploy it on SAP BTP or your internal infrastructure for enterprise use.

This quick start gives you the foundation — the next step is making your agent truly yours.

 

References

  • Example Payloads for Inferencing - SAP AI Core Hosted | SAP Help Portal
  • Prompt LLMs in the generative AI hub in SAP AI Core & Launchpad | SAP Tutorials

entry.title: Low Code No Code Agentic AI systems and tools
entry.content:
Low Code No Code AI Agents

We are in the era of AI Agents, as such the demand for faster development to deployment of AI Agents is the need of the hour and this has resulted in an unprecedent increase in the need for citizen developers to step up their game. Forrester estimates the combined low-code and digital process automation (DPA) market, which was valued at $13.2 billion at the end of 2023, could reach $50 billion by 2028 if fuelled by the growth of AI (a 33% annual growth rate).  93% of developers spend at least some of their time using low-code tools. Enterprises are adopting low-code solutions for their flexibility (83%), speed (63%), and process automation capabilities (67%). The technology frees up professional developers from routine tasks, allowing them to focus on more complex, strategic projects.

In this blog, we will be exploring the below concepts:

  • Traditional AI vs Low Code No Code (LCNC) AI approach for building & training AI
  • Agentic AI vs Chatbots
  • Core building blocks for an Agent
  • Agent Design Framework
  • Types of Agentic AI & Reasoning approaches in AI
  • LCNC External Tools

Traditional AI vs No Code AI

 

Image  1 : Traditional AI training & deployment approach

 

Image  2 : LCNC training & deployment approach

 The differences between the two are illustrated in the table as below:

 

Feature

Code-based approach

Low Code No-code approach

Speed to Prototype

Slower due to coding, debugging, and testing

Faster with visual tools and pre-built components

Ease of Use

Requires programming skills, steep learning curve

Accessible to non-technical users, low learning curve

Custom Logic & Control

High customization, full control over logic

Limited customization, relies on pre-built components

API Integration

Flexible, integrates with any API

Pre-built connectors for popular APIs, less flexible

Scalability

Highly scalable, handles large datasets and complex tasks

Limited scalability, depends on platform capabilities

AI Agent Complexity

Supports complex, autonomous agents

Best for simpler, static workflows

Teamwork

Requires technical expertise, supports version control

Enables collaboration with non-technical users via visual interfaces

Debug and maintain

Challenging for complex systems, robust debugging tools available

Easier for simple workflows, complex issues may need platform support

Data Privacy

Greater control, requires proper implementation

Relies on platform’s security, some offer strong compliance

Cost

Higher initial costs, cost-effective for large-scale projects

Subscription-based, cost-effective for small to medium projects

 

Agentic AI vs Chat Bot

An AI Agent is one which is capable of Thinking. It’s not a static rule-based automation system, it can comprehend its environment and its parameters and variable, reason and come to a decision.

Take action to accomplish a goal.
Function without continual human input

Chatbots on the other hand often lack the ability to reason and are not equipped to learn and process information to act on the go.

Takeaway: AI agents don’t just follow instructions – they adapt, reason, and make decisions based on context rather than rigid rules, in contrast to classical automation or is limited to text/image generation.

Three core building blocks of an Agentic AI system are as follows:

  1. Reasoning and Planning divides large objectives into manageable steps considers multiple steps rather than a single shot and modifies the plan considering fresh information
      
  2. Utilizing Tools to accomplish the listed tasks to achieve the said goal. Additionally, AI Agents intelligence is also the ability to select the appropriate tool at the appropriate time.
  3. Recollection Short-term memory: context of tasks and conversations Long-term memory: gains knowledge from previous exchanges gradually becomes better rather than making the same mistakes.

 

 

Image  3 : Three core blocks of an AI Agent

 

Agent Design Frameworks = Methods LLMs Use to Think, Act & Work Together.

Agentic AI is created by constructing one or more LLMs to collaborate effectively. This area is developing — and your designs can transform into frameworks as well.

Fundamental Agent Design Patterns are as below:

 

  1. Reflection  - "How was my performance?" - The agent assesses its own results and enhances upcoming replies.
  2. Utilization of Tools - “What can assist me?” - Agents utilize resources such as web searches, APIs, databases, or code execution to accomplish tasks.
  3. Planning - “What is the most effective path ahead?” - The agent breaks tasks into step-by-step plans and executes them intelligently.
  4. Multi-Agent Collaboration - “Let’s ponder together.” - Numerous agents discuss, cooperate, or split tasks with collective or individual objectives.

The Core Idea
Agentic AI isn’t just about building smarter models:
It’s about creating smarter ways to think, act, and collaborate.

Types of Reasoning Approaches in Agent AI

Reasoning is the ability of the LLM to make decisions like a human in the absence of the human.

  1. Prompt-based reasoning - You write a detailed prompt asking an agent to build a marketing plan for a company, comparing it with the competition for the best possible approach that will work for this company. You could automate this as an agent AI task. The agent AI will execute this prompt and reason at every step to achieve the requested outcome and present a marketing plan. 
  2. Reasoning with action (ReAct) - An agent AI tracks the safety of a manufacturing plant and makes decisions based on several inputs provided. It also takes input from the environment, which it incorporates into its reasoning to change its action plan. For example, there could be high moisture levels caused by a pipe leak. The agent may change its actions based on this data.
  3. Reasoning without observation (ReWOO) - An agent AI finds the right product for a customer to buy based on their behavioural data. It does not take any other input to change its decision.

Low-Code / No-Code Agentic AI Platforms

A low-code AI agent builder is a framework or platform that lets you define agent behaviour declaratively, rather than imperatively.

A low-code AI agent builder is a platform or framework that enables you to define agent behaviour declaratively rather than imperatively. Instead of writing extensive orchestration code, you simply describe what the agent should do.

  1. Goals
  2. Capabilities
  3. Tools
  4. Constraints
  5. Execution flow

The builder handles:

  1. Agent lifecycle
  2. Context propagation
  3. Tool execution
  4. Memory
  5. Retries
  6. Workflow coordination

 

We have described some of the tools as below:

Visual Builder Platforms

 

Platform

Description

Key Capabilities

Best Suited For

Pricing / Licensing

Gumloop

No-code platform to visually create and deploy AI agents using a drag-and-drop canvas

• Intuitive flowchart-style UI
• Strong workflow automation focus
• Often described as “if Zapier and ChatGPT had a baby”

Business users building automation-first agents

Free plan available; paid plans start at $97/month

Langflow

Python-based platform for building AI apps, focused on single-agent systems and RAG

• Open-source foundation
• Deep LangChain integration
• Supports OpenAI, Hugging Face, TensorFlow
• AI-centric workflows

Developers & advanced users who want visual control with code extensibility

Open-source

Flowise

Visual editor using LangChain-style abstractions for LLM and tool orchestration

• Flexible model integration
• Custom tools & extensions
• Open-source with active community
• Strong LLM orchestration focus

Teams building customizable LLM pipelines visually

Open-source

 Enterprise Platforms

Platform

Description

Key Capabilities

Best Suited For

Enterprise Strengths

Microsoft Copilot Studio

Platform to build and deploy AI agents within the Microsoft ecosystem

• Deep Microsoft 365 integration
• Customer query handling
• Sales lead identification
• “AI employees” concept

Enterprises already invested in Microsoft stack

Enterprise-grade security, governance, compliance

Google Vertex AI Agent Builder

Google Cloud’s low-code platform for conversational agent creation

• Visual LLM workflow design
• Native Google Cloud integration
• High scalability
• Custom APIs & system instructions

Cloud-native enterprises on GCP

Scalability, performance, cloud-native controls

IBM AgentLab (Watsonx.ai)

Low-code drag-and-drop agent builder within IBM’s AI ecosystem

• RBAC, GDPR, HIPAA compliance
• Advanced governance tools
• Highly customizable agents

Regulated industries and large enterprises

Strong governance, compliance, enterprise controls

 

 Types of Agentic AI systems

 

Agent Type

Core Behaviour

Decision Basis

Environment Awareness

Adaptability

Example Use Case

Simple Action Agent

Acts when a condition is met

Predefined rules

Minimal (current input only)

None

Sprinkler turns on when temperature exceeds threshold

Model-Based Agent

Acts based on an internal model of the environment

Current state + internal model

Moderate (tracks environment state)

Limited

Vacuum cleaner detecting and collecting spills

Goal-Oriented Agent

Chooses actions to reach a defined goal

Goal distance & outcome evaluation

High

High (adjusts actions dynamically)

Chatbot scheduling patient appointments

Learning Agent

Learns from experience and self-improves

Feedback, reflection, performance evaluation

Very high

Continuous

Self-improving agent that refines decisions over time

Utility-Based Agent

Optimizes multiple variables while reaching a goal

Utility function (cost, speed, efficiency)

Very high

High

Autonomous delivery robot optimizing route and energy

 

In conclusion, while the surge of Agentic AI tools offers exciting possibilities, adopting them isn’t just about jumping on the latest trend. Organizations must weigh the cost of implementation and ongoing maintenance, ensure data privacy and security, and carefully evaluate risks, ethical implications, and environmental impact. Thoughtful planning and responsible deployment will determine whether Agentic AI becomes a true enabler of innovation or an expensive experiment.

entry.title: Deep Insert Payload into a Single table in RAP ABAP
entry.content:
This document demonstrates how to design and implement a RAP-based create scenario with a nested payload using the RESTful ABAP Programming Model (RAP). The example focuses on inserting data into a single custom database table using a root entity with a composition child, allowing a structured payload that includes both product and inventory-related information. The solution covers the full RAP flow: creating the database table, defining Interface Views and Projection Views with compositions, implementing managed behavior with an unmanaged save, handling the payload in the behavior saver class, and finally exposing the data through a service definition and service binding. The scenario is validated by consuming the OData service with a JSON payload that creates the record successfully.

Payload to be passed to insert the record 

{ 
        "ProductId" : "00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000987", 
        "Name" : "Kumar111", 
        "to_InventoryReceipt" : 
                         {       
                              "Category" : "Transport", 
                                "Price" : 200, 
                                  "Currency" : "USD" 
                          }, 
        "Discount" : 30
}

Here all the fields' data are from the same table.

 

1. Create your table in which your payload is to be inserted.

2. Create Interface Views as given below.

 

@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED 
@EndUserText.label: 'product root view' 
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true 
define root view entity ZI_vbProduct_tmp_vw 
  as select from zvb_product_tmp as product 
composition [0..1] of ZI_InventoryReceipt_IFD_SEG as _InventoryReceipt 
{ 
  key product.product_id      as ProductId, 
      product.name           as Name, 
      product.discount       as Discount, 
      product.createdby      as CreatedBy, 
      _InventoryReceipt 
} 

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]  
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED  
@EndUserText.label: 'ZI_InventoryReceipt_IFD_SEG' 
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true 
@ObjectModel.usageType:{  
serviceQuality: #X,  
sizeCategory: #S,  
dataClass: #MIXED  
}  
define view entity ZI_InventoryReceipt_IFD_SEG 
  as select from zvb_product_tmp  
  association to parent ZI_vbProduct_tmp_vw as _Product 
    on $projection.ProductId = _Product.ProductId 
{ 
  key product_id   as ProductId, 
      category    as Category, 
      price       as Price, 
      currency    as Currency, 
       _Product 
}

Projection Views 

Create the projection views for the Interface Views.

@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED 
@EndUserText.label: 'product projection view' 
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true 
define root view entity ZP_Product as projection on ZI_vbProduct_tmp_vw 
{ 
@UI.facet: [{  
purpose: #STANDARD,  
position: 10,  
label: 'Product',  
type: #IDENTIFICATION_REFERENCE  
},  
{  
purpose: #STANDARD,  
position: 20,  
label: 'Inventory',  
type: #LINEITEM_REFERENCE,  
targetElement: '_InventoryReceipt'  
}]  
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 10, label: 'ProductId' }]  
@UI.identification: [{ position: 10, label: 'ProductId' }]  
    key ProductId, 
    .lineItem: [{ position: 20, label: 'Name' }]  
@UI.identification: [{ position: 20, label: 'Name' }]  
    Name, 
    .lineItem: [{ position: 30, label: 'Discount' }]  
@UI.identification: [{ position: 30, label: 'Discount' }]  
    Discount, 
    .lineItem: [{ position: 40, label: 'CreatedBy' }]  
@UI.identification: [{ position: 40, label: 'CreatedBy' }]  
    CreatedBy, 
    /* Associations */ 
    _InventoryReceipt : redirected to composition child ZP_inventory 
} 

@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED 
@EndUserText.label: 'ZP_inventory' 
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true 
define view entity ZP_inventory as projection on ZI_InventoryReceipt_IFD_SEG 
{ 
@UI.facet: [{  
purpose: #STANDARD,  
position: 10,  
label: 'Inventory',  
type: #IDENTIFICATION_REFERENCE  
}]  
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 50, label: 'ProductId' }]  
@UI.identification: [{ position: 50, label: 'ProductId' }]  
    key ProductId, 
    .lineItem: [{ position: 60, label: 'Category' }]  
@UI.identification: [{ position: 60, label: 'Category' }]  
    Category, 
    .lineItem: [{ position: 70, label: 'Price' }]  
@UI.identification: [{ position: 70, label: 'Price' }]  
    Price, 
    .lineItem: [{ position: 80, label: 'Currency' }]  
@UI.identification: [{ position: 80, label: 'Currency' }]  
    Currency, 
    /* Associations */ 
    _Product   : redirected to parent ZP_Product 
}

 

Create Behaviour definition on Interface View. 

 

Behaviour Definition for projection views 

 

managed with unmanaged save implementation in class zbp_i_vbproduct_tmp_vw unique; 
strict ( 2 ); 
define behavior for ZI_VBPRODUCT_tmp_VW alias product_tmp 
//late numbering 
lock master 
authorization master ( instance ) 
//etag master <field_name> 
//early numbering 
{ 
  create; 
  update; 
  delete; 
  association _InventoryReceipt { create ; } 
}
define behavior for ZI_INVENTORYRECEIPT_IFD_SEG 
lock dependent by _Product 
//early numbering 
authorization dependent by _Product 
{ 
  association  _Product; 
  update; 
  delete; 
  field ( readonly ) productid; 
}

 

projection; 
strict ( 2 ); 
define behavior for ZP_Product alias Product 
{ 
  use create; 
  use update; 
  use delete; 
  use association _InventoryReceipt { create; } 
} 
define behavior for ZP_inventory alias Inventory 
{ 
  use update; 
  use delete; 
  use association _Product; 
}

 Behaviour Implementation 

CLASS lhc_product_tmp DEFINITION INHERITING FROM cl_abap_behavior_handler. 

  PRIVATE SECTION. 
    METHODS get_instance_authorizations FOR INSTANCE AUTHORIZATION 
      IMPORTING keys REQUEST requested_authorizations FOR product_tmp RESULT result. 

*          METHODS earlynumbering_create FOR NUMBERING 
*      IMPORTING entities FOR CREATE ZI_VBPRODUCT_tmp_VW. 

ENDCLASS. 

CLASS lhc_product_tmp IMPLEMENTATION. 
  METHOD get_instance_authorizations. 
  ENDMETHOD. 

*  METHOD earlynumbering_create. 
*  endmethod. 

ENDCLASS. 

CLASS lsc_ZI_VBPRODUCT_TMP_VW DEFINITION INHERITING FROM cl_abap_behavior_saver. 

  PROTECTED SECTION. 

    METHODS save_modified REDEFINITION. 
     METHODS cleanup_finalize REDEFINITION. 
ENDCLASS. 

CLASS lsc_ZI_VBPRODUCT_TMP_VW IMPLEMENTATION. 
  METHOD save_modified. 

*  create-product_tmp 

data: lt_product_tmp type table for change zi_vbproduct_tmp_vw\\product_tmp. 

data: lt_zi_inventoryreceipt_ifd_seg type table for change zi_inventoryreceipt_ifd_seg. 

data: lt_final type table of zvb_product. 
MOVE-CORRESPONDING create-product_tmp to lt_product_tmp. 
MOVE-CORRESPONDING create-zi_inventoryreceipt_ifd_seg to lt_zi_inventoryreceipt_ifd_seg. 
LOOP AT lt_product_tmp into data(ls_product). 
read TABLE lt_zi_inventoryreceipt_ifd_seg into data(ls_invent) index 1. 
append value #( product_id = cl_system_uuid=>create_uuid_x16_static( ) 
                name = ls_product-Name 
                Discount = ls_product-Discount 
                Category = ls_invent-Category 
                currency = ls_invent-Currency 
                price = ls_invent-Price ) to lt_final. 
endloop. 

modify zvb_product from TABLE lt_final. 
  ENDMETHOD. 
  METHOD cleanup_finalize. 
  ENDMETHOD. 
ENDCLASS.

Service Definition 

 

 

@EndUserText.label: 'SD FOR PRODUCT' 
define service ZSD_PRODUCT_TMP { 
  expose ZP_Product; 
  expose ZP_inventory; 
}

 

 

Service Binding 

 

 

Payload to be passed to insert the record 

{ 
        "ProductId" : "00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000987", 
        "Name" : "Kumar111", 
        "to_InventoryReceipt" : 
     { 
                                                              "Category" : "Transport", 
                                                              "Price" : 200, 
                                                              "Currency" : "USD" 
}, 
        "Discount" : 30 
 
}

 

URI  

/sap/opu/odata/sap/ZSB_PRODUCT_TEMP_V2/ZP_Product 

OUTPUT

Conclusion

                 By using RAP compositions and managed behavior with an unmanaged save implementation, this approach enables handling complex, nested payloads in a clean and extensible way. Even though all fields originate from the same database table, the logical separation into a root entity and a composition child improves API design and aligns with RAP best practices. The service definition and binding expose the entities for OData consumption, making it easy to create records using a single POST request with a structured payload. This design provides flexibility for future enhancements, ensures clear separation of responsibilities, and integrates seamlessly with SAP Fiori applications and external consumers.

Thank You 

Bharath Kumar VADDEPALLI
